We can assume that a minimal solution to `a ^ 4 + b ^ 4 = c ^ 2` has `a` odd.

type: ∀ {a b c : ℤ}, Fermat42 a b c → ∃ a0 b0 c0, Fermat42.Minimal a0 b0 c0 ∧ a0 % 2 = 1
name: Fermat42.exists_odd_minimal
docString: We can assume that a minimal solution to `a ^ 4 + b ^ 4 = c ^ 2` has `a` odd.

An integer is odd if and only if it is not even. In other words, an integer is odd if and only if it cannot be expressed as the sum of two equal integers.

name: Mathlib.Data.Int.Parity._auxLemma.4
docString: An integer is odd if and only if it is not even. In other words, an integer is odd if and only if it cannot be expressed as the sum of two equal integers.

The theorem `Nat.bodd_mul` states that for any two natural numbers `m` and `n`, the binary oddity (being odd or even) of their product `m * n` is equivalent to the logical conjunction (AND) of the binary oddities of `m` and `n` individually. In other words, the product of two natural numbers is odd if and only if both numbers are odd.

name: Nat.bodd_mul
docString: The theorem `Nat.bodd_mul` states that for any two natural numbers `m` and `n`, the binary oddity (being odd or even) of their product `m * n` is equivalent to the logical conjunction (AND) of the binary oddities of `m` and `n` individually. In other words, the product of two natural numbers is odd if and only if both numbers are odd.

If `b` is odd, then `J(-a | b) = χ₄ b * J(a | b)`.

type: ∀ (a : ℤ) {b : ℕ}, Odd b → jacobiSym (-a) b = ZMod.χ₄ ↑b * jacobiSym a b
name: jacobiSym.neg
docString: If `b` is odd, then `J(-a | b) = χ₄ b * J(a | b)`.

For any natural numbers n and even a, n is odd if and only if the remainder of n divided by a is odd.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Even a → (Odd (n % a) ↔ Odd n)
name: Odd.mod_even_iff
docString: For any natural numbers n and even a, n is odd if and only if the remainder of n divided by a is odd.

This theorem states that for any two natural numbers `a` and `b`, `a` is a divisor of the product of `b` and `a`. In the context of number theory, if we multiply `a` with any natural number `b`, `a` will always divide the resulting product.

name: Nat.dvd_mul_left
docString: This theorem states that for any two natural numbers `a` and `b`, `a` is a divisor of the product of `b` and `a`. In the context of number theory, if we multiply `a` with any natural number `b`, `a` will always divide the resulting product.

If `n` is odd and `a` is even, then `n % a` is odd.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Odd n → Even a → Odd (n % a)
name: Odd.mod_even
docString: If `n` is odd and `a` is even, then `n % a` is odd.

A natural number is odd if and only if it is not even, or equivalently, a natural number is odd if and only if it can be expressed as 2 times an integer plus one, while an even number can be expressed as the sum of two integers.

name: Nat.odd_iff_not_even
docString: A natural number is odd if and only if it is not even, or equivalently, a natural number is odd if and only if it can be expressed as 2 times an integer plus one, while an even number can be expressed as the sum of two integers.

This theorem states that for any two integers `a` and `b`, if both `a` and `b` are greater than zero, then their product is also greater than zero. In other words, the product of two positive integers is always a positive integer.

name: Int.mul_pos
docString: This theorem states that for any two integers `a` and `b`, if both `a` and `b` are greater than zero, then their product is also greater than zero. In other words, the product of two positive integers is always a positive integer.

If `a` is even, then `n` is odd iff `n % a` is odd.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Even a → (Odd (n % a) ↔ Odd n)
name: Odd.mod_even_iff
docString: If `a` is even, then `n` is odd iff `n % a` is odd.

For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

This theorem states that for all integers `a` and `b`, the negation of the product of `a` and `b` is equal to the product of the negation of `a` and `b`. In other words, if we take any two integers, multiply them together, and then take the negation of the result, we will get the same value as if we had taken the negation of the first integer and then multiplied by the second integer. This theorem is a property of integer multiplication and follows from the well known fact that the multiplication of an integer by -1 results in the negation of the integer.

name: Int.neg_mul_eq_neg_mul
docString: This theorem states that for all integers `a` and `b`, the negation of the product of `a` and `b` is equal to the product of the negation of `a` and `b`. In other words, if we take any two integers, multiply them together, and then take the negation of the result, we will get the same value as if we had taken the negation of the first integer and then multiplied by the second integer. This theorem is a property of integer multiplication and follows from the well known fact that the multiplication of an integer by -1 results in the negation of the integer.

A natural number is odd iff it has residue `1` or `3` mod `4`

name: Nat.odd_mod_four_iff
docString: A natural number is odd iff it has residue `1` or `3` mod `4`

Two elements `a` and `b` are regular if and only if both products `a * b` and `b * a`
are regular.

type: ∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : Semigroup R] {a b : R}, IsRegular (a * b) ∧ IsRegular (b * a) ↔ IsRegular a ∧ IsRegular b
name: isRegular_mul_and_mul_iff
docString:
Two elements `a` and `b` are regular if and only if both products `a * b` and `b * a`
are regular.

If `a` is even, then `n` is even iff `n % a` is even.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Even a → (Even (n % a) ↔ Even n)
name: Even.mod_even_iff
docString: If `a` is even, then `n` is even iff `n % a` is even.

If `b` is odd, then `J(2 | b)` is given by `χ₈ b`.

type: ∀ {b : ℕ}, Odd b → jacobiSym 2 b = ZMod.χ₈ ↑b
name: jacobiSym.at_two
docString: If `b` is odd, then `J(2 | b)` is given by `χ₈ b`.
